chapters.theory:
JavaScript (JS) is a high-level, interpreted programming language primarily known as the scripting language for Web pages. It enables interactive web pages and is an essential part of web applications. Beyond the browser, JS is used in servers (Node.js), mobile apps (React Native), and desktop apps (Electron).

JavaScript is multi-paradigm, supporting event-driven, functional, and imperative programming styles. It is dynamically typed and follows the ECMAScript specification.

examples.title: Use in HTML
examples.code:
<script>
  console.log("Hello from Script tag");
</script>

examples.title: Console Output
examples.code: console.log("JS is running");

exercises.question: What is the standard specification for JavaScript?
Which environment allows JS to run on servers?

chapters.completion_criteria: Understands the role and versatility of JavaScript in modern development.

chapters.theory:
JavaScript can be executed directly in the browser console, embedded in HTML files, or run via Node.js. In a typical HTML setup, the `<script>` tag is placed at the end of the `<body>` to ensure the DOM is loaded before execution.

External scripts are linked using the `src` attribute of the script tag, promoting separation of concerns.

examples.title: External Script
examples.code: <script src="app.js"></script>

examples.title: Node.js Execution
examples.code:
// In terminal:
// node app.js

exercises.question: Which HTML tag is used to include JavaScript?
Where is the best place to put the script tag in HTML for performance?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can integrate and execute JavaScript in both browser and server environments.

chapters.theory:
Variables are containers for data. Modern JS uses `let` (block scoped, reassignable) and `const` (block scoped, constant reference). `var` is function-scoped and generally avoided in modern code.

Data types include Primitives (`String`, `Number`, `Boolean`, `Null`, `Undefined`, `Symbol`, `BigInt`) and Objects.

examples.title: Declaration
Types

exercises.question: Which keyword declares a constant variable?
What is the type of a variable that has been declared but not assigned?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can properly declare variables and identify data types.

chapters.theory:
JavaScript supports arithmetic (`+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`, `**`), assignment (`=`, `+=`), comparison (`==`, `===`, `!=`, `!==`, `>`, `<`), and logical (`&&`, `||`, `!`) operators. The strict equality operator `===` checks both value and type, preventing unwanted type coercion.

The ternary operator (`condition ? true : false`) provides a concise conditional expression.

examples.title: Ternary
examples.code: let status = age >= 18 ? "Adult" : "Minor";

exercises.question: What does `===` check?
Result of `'5' + 5`?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can construct expressions using strict operators to avoid common pitfalls.

chapters.theory:
Conditional logic dictates program flow. `if`, `else if`, and `else` blocks execute code based on boolean conditions. The `switch` statement selects a code block based on matching cases.

Falsy values in JS include `false`, `0`, `""`, `null`, `undefined`, and `NaN`.

examples.title: If-Else
Switch

exercises.question: Is an empty string `""` truthy or falsy?
Keyword to stop fall-through in switch?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can control program flow based on dynamic conditions.

chapters.theory:
Loops repeat a block of code. `for` loops are standard for definite iteration. `while` and `do-while` loops run based on conditions. The `for...of` loop is used to iterate over iterable objects like arrays.

`break` exits the loop entirely, while `continue` skips to the next iteration.

examples.title: For Loop
For...Of

exercises.question: Which loop is best for iterating array values?
Loop that guarantees at least one execution?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can automate repetitive tasks using various loop structures.

chapters.theory:
Functions are reusable blocks of code. They can be function declarations or expressions. ES6 introduced Arrow Functions (`=>`) which provide a shorter syntax.

Scope determines variable visibility: Global, Function, and Block scope (`let`/`const`).

examples.title: Arrow Function
examples.code:
const add = (a, b) => a + b;
console.log(add(2, 3));

examples.title: Scope

exercises.question: Define a function `greet` taking `name`.
Are variables defined with `let` inside an `if` block accessible outside?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can define modular functions and manage data visibility.

chapters.theory:
Arrays are ordered lists of values, potentially of mixed types. They are zero-indexed objects. Key properties include `.length`. Common operations involve accessing `[i]` and modifying elements.

Arrays in JS are dynamic and can grow or shrink automatically.

examples.title: Creation
examples.code:
const colors = ["Red", "Blue"];
console.log(colors[0]);

examples.title: Modification
examples.code:
colors.push("Green"); // Adds to end
colors.pop(); // Removes last

exercises.question: Method to add element to the end of an array?
Property to get the number of elements?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can store and manipulate lists of data using arrays.

chapters.theory:
Objects are collections of key-value pairs. Keys are strings (or Symbols), and values can be any type. Values are accessed via dot notation `obj.key` or bracket notation `obj['key']`.

Object literals `{}` are the primary way to create objects.

examples.title: Object Literal
Access
examples.code:
console.log(user.name);
console.log(user["age"]);

exercises.question: Notation to access property with a variable key?
Delete property `age` from object `user`.

chapters.completion_criteria: Can model real-world entities using JavaScript objects.

chapters.theory:
Strings are immutable sequences of characters. Template Literals (backticks ``) allow embedded expressions (`${var}`). Useful methods include `.slice()`, `.split()`, `.includes()`, and `.replace()`.

Strings behave like arrays of characters for read access.

examples.title: Template Literal
examples.code:
const name = "Bob";
const msg = `Hello, ${name}!`;

examples.title: Methods
examples.code:
const str = "JavaScript";
console.log(str.slice(0, 4)); // "Java"

exercises.question: Method to split string into array by delimiter?
Syntax for string interpolation?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can manipulate text efficiently using modern string features.

chapters.theory:
Higher-order array methods are essential for functional programming. `.map()` transforms elements, `.filter()` selects elements, and `.reduce()` accumulates a single result.

Other notable methods: `.find()`, `.some()`, `.every()`, and `.sort()`.

examples.title: Map & Filter
Reduce
examples.code: const sum = nums.reduce((acc, cur) => acc + cur, 0);

exercises.question: Method to create a new array with transformed elements?
Method to find the first matching element?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can process data collections using functional array methods.

chapters.theory:
Key concepts include default parameters, rest parameters (`...args`), and the `this` keyword context. `this` refers to the execution context; arrow functions lexically bind `this` (inherit from parent).

Immediately Invoked Function Expressions (IIFE) run immediately after definition.

examples.title: Default & Rest
Arrow `this`

exercises.question: Operator to gather remaining arguments into an array?
Do arrow functions have their own `this`?

chapters.completion_criteria: Understands advanced function mechanics and context binding.

chapters.theory:
ES6+ introduced massive quality-of-life improvements. Destructuring allows unpacking arrays/objects into variables. The Spread operator (`...`) expands iterables. Enhanced Object Literals simplify object creation.

`let` and `const` replaced `var` as standard.

examples.title: Destructuring
examples.code:
const [x, y] = [1, 2];
const { name } = { name: "Alice", age: 30 };

examples.title: Spread
examples.code:
const arr1 = [1, 2];
const arr2 = [...arr1, 3, 4];

exercises.question: Extract property `id` from object `user` into a variable.

chapters.completion_criteria: Writes modern, clean JavaScript using ES6+ syntax.

chapters.theory:
JavaScript uses `try...catch...finally` blocks to handle runtime errors gracefully. `throw` allows defining custom errors. The `Error` object contains a `message` and `stack` trace.

Handling errors prevents applications from crashing unexpectedly.

examples.title: Try-Catch
Custom Error
examples.code: if (!valid) throw new Error("Invalid Input");

exercises.question: Keyword to generate an error manually?
Does `finally` run if no error occurs?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can write robust code that anticipates and manages failures.

chapters.theory:
ES Modules (ESM) allow splitting code into separate files. `export` exposes variables/functions, and `import` brings them in. There are Named Exports and Default Exports.

Modern browsers support `<script type="module">`.

examples.title: Exporting
Importing
examples.code: import log, { add } from './math.js';

exercises.question: Keyword to export a single main value from a module?
Can you have multiple default exports?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can structure larger applications using modular architecture.

chapters.theory:
JavaScript is single-threaded but handles concurrency via the Event Loop. Asynchronous operations (timers, IO) don't block the main thread. Callbacks were the original way to handle async results.

`setTimeout` and `setInterval` are basic async scheduling functions.

examples.title: SetTimeout
Callback Hell

exercises.question: Function to execute code after a delay?
Is JavaScript multi-threaded?

chapters.completion_criteria: Understands the non-blocking nature of JavaScript.

chapters.theory:
Promises represent a value available now, later, or never. States: Pending, Fulfilled, Rejected. `async` functions return a Promise implicitly. `await` pauses execution until a Promise resolves.

This creates cleaner, synchronous-looking asynchronous code.

examples.title: Promise Chain
Async/Await

exercises.question: Keyword to pause function execution until promise resolves?
What does an `async` function return?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can manage complex asynchronous flows efficiently.

chapters.theory:
Modern JS uses `class` syntax, although it's syntactic sugar over prototypal inheritance. Key features: `constructor`, `extends` (inheritance), `static` methods, and getters/setters.

`super()` calls the parent constructor.

examples.title: Class Definition
Inheritance

exercises.question: Keyword to create a subclass?
Method called automatically when creating an instance?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can apply OOP principles in JavaScript.

chapters.theory:
A closure is a function bundled with its lexical environment. It 'remembers' variables from where it was created, even after the outer function has finished. Hoisting is the behavior where declarations are moved to the top of scope (var/function declarations).

Practical use of closures: Data privacy and factory functions.

examples.title: Closure
Hoisting
examples.code:
console.log(x); // undefined
var x = 5;

exercises.question: Can a returned function access variables of its parent function?
Are `let` declarations hoisted?
exercises.solution: Yes, but in Temporal Dead Zone

chapters.completion_criteria: Deeply understands scope mechanisms and memory behavior.

chapters.theory:
The Event Loop monitors the Call Stack and Callback Queue. If the stack is empty, it pushes tasks from the Queue (Macrotasks like setTimeout) or Microtask Queue (Promises) to the stack.

Microtasks have higher priority than Macrotasks.

examples.title: Execution Order

exercises.question: Which queue has higher priority: Callback or Microtask?
Does `setTimeout(fn, 0)` execute immediately?

chapters.completion_criteria: Can reason about execution order in complex async scenarios.

chapters.theory:
Interviews often test array manipulations (flattening, deduplicating), deep cloning objects, implementing polyfills (map, reduce, bind), and debouncing/throttling events.

Understanding `prototype` chain and `this` binding rules (`call`, `apply`, `bind`) is critical.

examples.title: Debounce
Flatten Array
examples.code:
const flat = arr => arr.reduce((acc, val) => 
  Array.isArray(val) ? acc.concat(flat(val)) : acc.concat(val), []);

exercises.question: Method to manually set `this` context for a function?

chapters.completion_criteria: Ready to solve algorithmic and structural problems in JS interviews.

chapters.theory:
Write clean code: Use `const` by default, descriptive naming, and prefer `async/await`. Avoid global variables. Use strict mode (`'use strict'`).

Performance: Minimize DOM access, avoid memory leaks (clear intervals), and use efficient algorithms.

examples.title: Clean Code
Strict Mode
examples.code:
'use strict';
x = 3.14; // Error (undeclared)

exercises.question: String to enable strict mode?
Default variable declaration to use?

chapters.completion_criteria: Writes maintainable, performant, and professional JavaScript code.
